newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Malaysian crime rate higher than Singapore - paper.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian crime rate higher than Singapore - paper.

text.p: The Straits Times newspaper trumpeted new figures on Monday that showed Singapore's crime rate is lower than Malaysia's, the latest salvo in a war of words that has seriously damaged relations.
Singapore's leading daily newspaper said the just-released 1997 edition of the World Competitiveness Yearbook "reports that Malaysia's crime rate has shot up and surpassed that of Singapore".
The statistics show Singapore with 37.4 serious crimes per 100,000 population in 1994 against 46.4 for Malaysia. In 1993, the figures were 13.2 for Malaysia against 43.8 for Singapore.
The yearbook is published by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management Development.

The 1993 numbers, from the 1996 edition of the yearbook, had been used earlier in Malaysian newspapers as evidence that Malaysia was safer than Singapore. That was part of a running dispute with Singapore which has been simmering for months.

It began when former Singapore prime minister Lee Kuan Yew said in a court affidavit made public early this year that Malaysia's Johor Bahru was "notorious for shootings, muggings and car-jackings", sparking a heated response from Malaysia.
Lee subsequently apologised and withdrew the remarks.

The Straits Times, however, used information presented by Lee to the court for an article suggesting that reports about crime in Johor, across a narrow strait from Singapore, would indeed have led people to conclude crime was a problem there.
That sparked fresh complaints from Malaysia, and a barrage of claims and counter-claims about crime rates.

The dispute has spilled over into other areas, including tourism, investment and shipping. The two countries "are going through difficult bilateral relations," Singapore Foreign Minister Shanmugan Jayakumar said on Saturday.
